item.title: How to Creat a PHP Template Website!
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

[center][size=15pt]How to Creat a PHP Template Website![/size]
by yours truly[/center]

This is a tutorial on how to create a PHP template which will include separate pieces of a webpage and include them into other web pages to make it easier.

Here is an example of an index.php that has a PHP template.

<?
// Includes the webpage in the folder website/top.php
Include("website/top.php");
// Includes the webpage in the folder website/left.php
Include("website/left.php");
// Includes the webpage in the folder website/home.php
Include("website/home.php");
// Includes the webpage in the folder website/bottom.php
Include("website/bottom.php");
?>

That piece of code will include all parts of your website. That way you won’t have to edit each page. You can just edit one of the included files and they will be included all over you website.

Alright here is an example.

You can change the included home.php for any of your other pages. Such as your jokes page could look like this.

<?
// Includes the webpage in the folder website/top.php
Include("website/top.php");
// Includes the webpage in the folder website/left.php
Include("website/left.php");
// Includes the webpage in the folder website/jokes.php
Include("website/jokes.php");
// Includes the webpage in the folder website/bottom.php
Include("website/bottom.php");
?>

Here is an idea of what top.php has.

<!-- Begin top.php -->
<html>
<head><title>Welcome to my Website - xxx porn xxx sex all night xxx</title></head>
<body>
<table width="750" border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
 <tr>
  <td align="center"><h3>Blah blah title text, image, flash, whatever</h3></td>
 </tr>
</table>
<!-- End top.php -->

Here is an idea of what left.php has.

<!-- Begin left.php -->
<table>
 <tr>
  <td valign="top">
   <table border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="150">
    <tr>
     <td>Menu</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <td>
      Link 1<br>
      Link 2<br>
      Link 3<br>
      Link 4<br>
     </td>
    </tr>
   </table>
  </td>
<!-- End Left.php -->

Here is an idea of what home.php has.

<!-- Begin home.php -->
  <td valign="top">
   <table border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="600">
    <tr>
     <td>Home</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <td>
      I saw a bird today. The bird was blue. Birds turn me on. Pidgeons turn me off. I don't like pidgeons.<br>
      Anyways... When I saw the pidgeon I instantly went for my gun in my nephew's closet.<br>
      He's always playing with toys haha. I got the gun and bolted outside to where the pidgeon lay.<br>
      It was confident, provoking me into aiming that gun at him. Angering me by his thick feathers<br>
      and masculinity. There was nothing I could do. I shot him.<br><br>
      Why? <br><br>
      He said his was bigger.. that bastard.
     </td>
    </tr>
   </table>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>
<!-- End home.php -->

Here is an idea of what bottom.php has.

<!-- Begin bottom.php -->
<table border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
 <tr>
  <td width="750" align="center">Copyright blah blah by Chika Chika wowwow</td>
 </tr>
</table>
</body>
</html>
<!-- End bottom.php -->

Now these are all different files. But when we put them together, they form a web page! 95% of websites use this. Including this forum. Each page wasn’t manually created, it’s created by different pieces! I hope you learned something from this. ;D

~Ron
